Name: The Devil's Crown: A Campaign for Fisful of Death – Tales of Horror
Description:
The Devil’s Crown is a campaign for Fistful of Lead: Tales of Horror. The campaign is a series of 6 linked scenarios to be played in order. The outcome of each scenario has a direct effect on the next game. The player with the most Renown at the end of the campaign wins, and possesses the dark power of the crown.

The scenario book also has rules for a new faction: Gypsies! Sometimes against, sometimes with the Forces of Darkness.

And a printable catacomb for use with scenario book.

"Few know that the War in Heaven was only surpassed in length and ferocity by the War in Hell. Soon after the Fall, Lucifer was faced with a power struggle of his own. The Legions of the Damned fought a fierce civil war for the Infernal Throne that lasted untold ages.
As a symbol of his victory over the fractious demons, the princes of Hell presented their Dread Lord with a crown. Forged in the very fires of Hell, the crown was a thing of terrible beauty, dripping with blood, and pulsing with malign power.
Not long after the coronation, the crown was stolen, perhaps by a disgruntled devil of the losing faction. It was hidden, it was said, in the mortal world. Many have sought it, few, thankfully, have found it. Those who do, usually meet with an untimely and painful end.”
- From the writings of Brother Theodoseus, just before his mysterious death in 1563

—description from the publisher

Name: Warr Without An Enemie: A Set of Wargaming Rules for the British Civil Wars 1639 - 1651
Description:
Warr Without An Enemie is a set of wargame rules for the English Civil War developed by the Wyre Forest Gamers. The English Civil War is notable because of the large number of small actions that happened during the war. These provide a variety of interesting historical battles to fight. The player commands one to three 'brigades'. Brigades are usually 3 to 6 units, with 4 to 6 bases of figures per unit. For non historical battles brigades are generated randomly to provide interesting challenges and opportunities for the players.

A base represents 60 to 100 infantry and half that for cavalry. The players decide how many figures to use per base and base size. Units lose bases of figures, not individual figures.

The emphasis on the rules is on command and managing unit disruption caused by battlefield action. Quality of the commanders and units is usually more important than numbers or weapons. Raw units will need constant vigilance to keep them in the action while hardened Veterans will sort themselves out, dust themselves off and carry on. Commanders have different command rating and also can have individual qualities to reflect their character. A commander can thus be 'Steadfast' and good in defensive situations or a 'Drunkard' and a loose cannon. Units can receive disorder from movement, manoeuvre, combat, friendly units suffering reverses, etc. Disorder adversely effects a units abilities and after the limit is reached will lead to loses of bases. High quality units and good commander have a better ability to remove disorder.

Infantry are rated in one of 7 categories, I1 to I7. The number indicates the number of muskets and pikes within the unit. I1 means the unit is an all musket unit, while an I7 unit is all pikes. Most units are of course in between these two extremes, two muskets to one pike is an I3 unit for example. All bases fire and melee so there is no need to exactly model the ratio of weapons. When firing you need to roll your I number or higher to hit, while if in melee you need you I number or lower to hit. In this way the mix of weapons within a unit is quickly reflected. For example: An I3 unit (2 muskets to 1 pike) needs to roll 3 or higher per base to hit when firing but an I5 unit (1 musket to 1 pike) must roll 5 or higher to hit. So when firing the I3 unit will have the advantage while in a melee the reverse is the case. In a close combat the I3 unit will need to roll 3 or less to hit, while the I5 unit will need 5 or less.

There are four kinds of mainstream cavalry along with lancers and dragoons. The four kinds of cavalry allow the representation of the tactics of the period that is not possible in many other rules and is, like much of the rest of the rules, based on modern research of this fascinating period. 'Pistoleers' rely on firepower. 'Gallopers' rely on the reckless speed of their charge and the sword. While the dominant tactics of the war are the Dutch and Swedish styles of fighting. Entering combat at a high speed is an advantage but runs the risk of getting more disorder. Shooting the attackers can stop the aggressors in their tracks and leave them open to counter attack. Yet if it doesn't work.........

The aim of the game is to provide a set of rules that combine modern views of the war with an innovative and entertaining game. In the future the rules will be expanded to cover other wars and work on the Thirty Years War is well on the way.

—description from the publisher

Name: Felicior Augusto, Melior Traiano ! II
Description:
Felicior Augusto, Melior Traiano ! II is an extension for the skimish rules Felicior Augusto, Melior Traiano ! adding the Huns and the Goths to the Vth century party.

for 25/30mm miniatures.

Sequence of play:

Initiative
    Actions (movement, corps-a-corps, throw)
    End of turn

Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 cm = 1 m

—user summary

Name: Le Blockhaus
Description:
Le Blockhaus easy D-day landing !

Miniature wargame rules for the 6th June 1944 US and Brits landings with 20mm (1/72) minis.
The goal is, for the Allies to capture the blockhaus as fast as possible, for the German player to delay as long as possible.
It is recommended to change sides after each game.

Sequence of play:
Post deployment the order is as follow:

     Allied soldiers movements phase
     Support landing crafts fire phase
     German soldiers movements phase 
     2nd Allied movements phase
     German fire phase
     Allied Fire phase


Roll for reinforcement

Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 model = 1 vehicle
1 cm = 1 m
1 turn = 20 sec

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Le Blockhaus 2
Description:
Le Blockhaus 2 is an expansion for Le Blockhaus.

It is a miniature (20mm - 1/72) skirmish wargame rules for D-Day. It introduces an updated sequence of play as well as Hobart's Funnies and other special rules.

Sequence of play:

    Post deployment the order is as follow:
         Allied movement phase
         Support landing crafts fire phase (1st turn only)
         German movement phase 
         German fire phase
         Allied Fire phase
    
    Roll for Allied reinforcements from turn 3


Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 model = 1 vehicle
1 cm = 1 m
1 turn = 20 sec

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Samourai
Description:
Samourai is a simple miniature skimish ruleset in Medieval Japan.

It is based on DBA to be played with 15mm minis. 25mm can be used too.

Sequence of play:
1st player phase:

     Move active player units
     Shooting of units not in contact
     Mêlée of units in contact


then 2nd player go through same sequence

Name: Miss Dessie Dots Jolly Dollar
Description:
A simple roll and move educational game teaching currency conversion from pounds/pence to decimal Australian dollars and cents. Australia changed over to decimalization in 1966.

By the roll of a dice players move along playing squares that have a money value up to 100 cents. Certain squares are red or green and when a player lands on these squares they must do a conversion from pence to cents. Correct conversion will see the player on a green square advance the cent value but on a red square go back the cent value. If the conversion is incorrect the player can go back to the start. First to reach 100 cents by exact throw is the winner.

—user summary

Name: 4 billion secrets
Description:
6 heroes are on a trip to the Asian continent, where 4 billion people live. Every person on that continent has their own secrets and stories to tell.
You are one of the heroes and by facing challenges and answering questions correctly within a given time you can collect badges.
The first player to gather 6 badges (2 of each category) wins the game.

Name: Dino Safari
Description:
On an uncharted island somewhere on Pacific Ocean you came across something that no one expected... Dinosaurs! But you fear nobody is going to believe you. That's why you need to take photos of them.

Explore the island, take many photos but beware, dinosaurs are not used to visitors. Some will flee but other may find you tasty! You will not be able to show your photos when you're eaten. Also remember that it's not the quantity of photos that count but quality. Big and dangerous dinosaurs are worth more points than small, easier to find ones.

Let the Dino Safari begin!

During setup players are required to create the "island" using tiles with hexagonal spaces starting with "camp" tile. Once it's done 12 randomly chosen dinosaur tokens are randomly placed on "nest" spaces facing down. Then each player choose their character and place him/her in the camp. Players take their turns clockwise. During player's turn you have three movement points and one "take a picture" action. You can spend those in any order you want. Characters can move in any direction they want, "plains" space costs 1 movement point while "forest" space costs 2. You cannot enter "crags" or "lake" spaces. To take a photo move to a space adjacent to dinosaur token and uncover it then take the card with species you've uncovered. On each species card you can see how much points it's worth and its skills like movement points and special rules. Players can also take pictures of already uncovered dinos to get their cards but you can score only once for each species. Starting with round two after you're done with your character's actions you can move 1 uncovered dinosaur token (you must be in possession of that species card). You can use that to run away from other players, scare off another uncovered dinosaur to remove its token so nobody can take a picture of it anymore or, if it's a carnivore, attack other players. Attacked player loses one life and is forced to return to camp. If a character is attacked third time (losing last remaining life) he/she is considered "eaten" and eliminated from game (his/her score is 0 no matter how many cards were in his/her possession). From now on during eliminated player's turn he/she can only move dinosaurs. Game ends when all 12 tokens are uncovered. The sum of points on cards in your possession is your score. Highest score wins. There is also a chance that all players are eaten. In that rare case game ends and nobody wins.

Name: La Petite Guerre: Skirmishing on the Frontiers of Empire – The Great War for Empire in America
Description:
La Petite Guerre is a miniatures skirmish game for 18th century North America, featuring English and French regulars, colonial militias, American rebels, coureurs des bois, and Indian warbands.

In a turn, chits are drawn to determine which player gets to activate a figure, which then does all it's movement, shooting, etc. before the next chit is drawn. Not enough chits are used to allow all figures to activate, and a figure is allowed to activate twice in a turn, at the cost of the opportunity to activate another at all.

Shooting and melee are resolved by rolling dice, applying various modifiers, and looking up the result in a table. Movement allowances are similarly rolled for.

—user summary

Name: Come to the Fair
Description:
Contained in the book Fairground Games to Make and Play by Neil and Ruth Thomson. An entirely luck-based spin and move game, but different from many such games, since every space is an intersection with 4 possible directions to another space: forwards, backwards, left, and right. The spinner (to be constructed) has these directions (F, B, L, and R) as possible results, and players must go one space in the direction they spin. 
The goal is to reach the fair before other players. One is required to get an F on the spinner to begin. Some directions from spaces lead to dead ends; players who get spinner results telling them to go to a dead end must remain where they are that turn.

—user summary

Name: Shepherds & Wolves
Description:
Shepherds and Wolves is a handcrafted board game for 2 players. It's easy to learn and tests your defensive and offensive game strategies.

This game is great for the young, old, and in between. My 5-year-old daughter loves playing the game.

Gameplay takes place in a lovely meadow. Shepherds work to rid the meadow of wolves. Wolves work to rid the meadow of sheep.

The shepherds are slow, but they are persistent. They can move at most three spaces as they try to remove all the wolves from the meadow. The wolves cannot harm them. Once the last wolf is removed from the board, the shepherds have won.

The wolves move fast and work in a pack. They can move up to 6 spaces as they try to eat all of the nine sheep. Once the last sheep has been eaten, the wolves have won.

—description from the publisher

Name: For the Pharaoh: Wargames Rules for the Bronze and Chariot Age 3000BC-1000BC
Description:
Miniatures wargames for the Bronze Age, ca 3000-1000 BC.

The ground scale is 1:1000 and the figure ratio is 1:50 for most troops, allowing fairly large battles to be fought. Note however that for chariots the ratio is only two vehicles per model, so recreating the large numbers of chariots reported in Egyptian and Assyrian sources will be a challenge!

Troops are characterized by class (regular or irregular), morale class (from A+ elites to E dregs), type (infantry, chariotry, etc.), order (close, loose, or open), armour, and weaponry.

Play is IGO-UGO, and uses written orders that need to be carried to the units to execute them by messengers.

—user summary

Name: The Walking Dead: All Out War – Abraham
Description:
Web-exclusive alternate miniature

Ex-military, with a short temper and skill with firearms, Abraham appears violent and cold to others. He is actually as scared as any of the other survivors, and eventually comes to rely on them to survive the walkers.

—description from the publisher
Families: Game: The Walking Dead – All Out War

Name: From Gilgamesh to Grant
Description:
Have you ever wanted a rule system that was flexible enough to handle battles from the earliest days of recorded history? have you ever wanted a system that is capable of handling battles of truly massive sizes? Have you ever wanted a game that gave Skirmishers and light cavalry the impact and respect you always thought they were lacking in other games? Well, then the game you are looking at is the game for you.

Features:


    an expansive and versatile rule set able to fight the campaigns of Gilgamesh or Grant and any in between.
    simple combat resolution mechanics. now improved for speed
    plays well on a standard six foot by four-foot table, reducing space needed for a large game.
    Traits have been improved.
    New weather effects on the battle.


—description from publisher

Name: The Walking Dead: All Out War – Negan
Description:
Web-exclusive alternate miniature

Negan is a savage man who adores mayhem, violence, and profane language and has a knack for manipulating others. He uses this to rule over his people, ‘The Saviors’ with an iron fist, and becomes Rick’s most terrifying enemy to date.

—description from the publisher
Families: Game: The Walking Dead – All Out War

Name: From Gilgamesh to Grant: In Those Ancient Days
Description:
The first expansion for From Gilgamesh to Grant adds 23 new armies covering the period leading up to the eve of Romes ascendancy. This is not a stand-alone product it is an expansion upon the core rules found into From Gilgamesh to Grant.

—description from publisher

Name: The Walking Dead: All Out War – Michonne
Description:
Web-exclusive alternate miniature

Michonne appeared quite literally from nowhere, clad in a hooded poncho, brandishing a katana, and with two partially dismembered biters chained to her sides. Upon greeting Rick, she relinquished her weapon and joined the survivors inside their stronghold.

Contains:

     1 Plastic Miniature
     1 Character Card
     1 Equipment Card


—description from the publisher
Families: Game: The Walking Dead – All Out War

Name: Shipwreck: Scenario 01 – The battle of Latakia
Description:
A ready to play scenario based on the battle of Latakia, the first ever guided missile engagement in modern naval warfare.

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action, results and long-term consequences.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved.



     Instructions to set up the scenario, starting positions, victory conditions, variation rules, and



     a solo play option.

Name: Tiny Epic Dinosaurs: Laboratory Mini Expansion
Description:
The Laboratory Mini Expansion introduces certain rewards to players during play, like extra dinosaurs, resources, or research cards. To unlock these rewards, players follow research paths marked on their Laboratory Mats.

During setup, and at the start of each round, Lab Tokens are randomly placed above each Action Mat. When a player places a Rancher on an Action Mat, if there is a Lab Token there, that player must follow that research path on their Laboratory Mat. The Lab Token is then discarded. Once a player reaches a reward, they receive it immediately and reset their Microscope Token to the center of the Laboratory Mat.

The Laboratory Mini Expansion adds layers of thinking to a player's strategy when placing their Ranchers to take actions. If a player can synergize their action choices with the research paths they desire on their Laboratory Mat, they can accomplish more with fewer actions putting them ahead of their competition!

—description from the publisher

Name: MIG 5
Description: Fifth new version of the original M.I.G. quiz-game. As the previous it contains 1560 questions in five categories. New questions (2012) made for the swedish market and players over 15 years.

Name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game – Where the Gods Dwell: Mythos Pack
Description:
Come face to face with madness in Where the Gods Dwell, the fifth Mythos Pack in The Dream-Eaters cycle for Arkham Horror: The Card Game! After your seemingly endless journey across the Dreamlands, you have made your way to the land of Leng, an icy wasteland where you believe the peak of unknown Kadath resides. All the while, a presence taunts you, gnawing at your insides—a wordless voice you cannot hear, but feel within the confines of your mind. A presence that is waiting for you.

Where the Gods Dwell is Scenario 4–A of The Dream-Quest campaign. This scenario can be played on its own in Standalone Mode or combined with the other expansions in The Dream-Eaters cycle to form a larger four-part or eight-part campaign. After the events of Dark Side of the Moon, you have finally made your way to lost Kadath, where Nyarlathotep is waiting for a battle that will force you to face deceit, lies, and shifting reality. If you can somehow draw him out, expose him, you may stand a chance, but how do you fight an enemy you cannot understand?

—description from the publisher
Families: Game: Arkham Horror – The Card Game
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – The Dream-Eaters
Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: ATS Dien Bien Phu 2016
Description:
Dien Bien Phu, FRENCH INDOCHINA, 28 March 1954: By March 27th, General DeCastries faced a major problem: how to deal with the Viet Minh AA-guns that were seriously hampering his efforts at air resupply for the garrison. He decided that the next day he would send a large strike out to the west of the garrison’s position, tasked to capture a nest of AA batteries near the villages of Bang Ong Pet, and Ban Ban. The man he chose for the job was the most respected leader in the French garrison: Major Marcel Bigeard, affectionately known by a nick-name earned during his days in the resistance: Bruno. Behind a powerful barrage and ample air support the French attack came in. The 6th BPC (Colonial Parachute Battalion) struck Bang Ong Pet while the 8th BPC struck Ban Ban. The 8th achieved its objectives quickly, but the 6th was pinned down by stiff resistance. Three Chaffee tanks came up to reinforce the latter French assault and Viet Minh resistance soon gave way. When it was over the French were astounded at their success. Not only had they captured five 20mm AA-guns, twelve 12.7 AA MGs, and killed some 350 of the enemy, but they had done it against the elite 308th division, viewed by both armies to be the best unit the Viet Minh possessed.

Game components include:

9 maps measuring 18.5" x 12.5"
3 countersheets (1 x Viet Minh, 1 x French Infantry/Light Weapons, 1 x Vehicles)
9 AFV cards
4 scenario cards containing 7 scenarios
4 page battlefield walkaround
1 page player aid

The game depicts the action around the Eliane strongpoints of Dien Bien Phu.

Scenarios included:

The Battle for the “Five Hills” – Positions at “Eliane 1,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 31st 1954
    In French Hands - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 31st 1954
    Death by Pale Moonlight – Positions at “Champs Elysees,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 30th 1954
    In the Shadow of Bazilles - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, May 6th 1954
    The Last Day – Positions at “Elaine 4,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, May 7th 1954
    Mop Up - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, April 2nd 1954
    Under Old Baldy – Champs Elysees, French Indochina, April 4th 1954

Requires ownership of the ATS Rulebook 2014 + small and large markers.

-description from publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Idaho-opoly
Description: Monopoly with an Idaho flavor. Buy your favorite Idaho properties, increase your rent by collecting Small Towns and trading them in for Big Cities. Add in some snowfall, mountain biking, and a three day epic lift ticket and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun!

Name: Mini-MIG 2
Description:
A new release in 2010 of the previous Mini-M.I.G. from 2006. This version adds the M.I.G.-die from the original M.I.G.

Travel version of M.I.G. with 380 questions in five categories (Present & Past, Entertainment & Culture, Near & Far, Sports & Other, Nature & Science).

Two dice are rolled, one to decide category and one to decide if you have a 'M.I.G-chance'. If the player didn't roll a 'M.I.G-chance' they have to answer the question correct to have another roll of the dice. If the player has a 'M.I.G-chance' they have the opportunity to score, either way it's the next players turn.

The first player to correctly answer a 'M.I.G-chance' in each category is the winner.

Name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Westeros Draft Pack
Description:
Westeros is the second draft pool for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Draft Play, consisting of 240 randomized cards, including a healthy representation of cards from the Kingsroad and Conquest and Defiance cycles, as well as no fewer than thirty-four preview cards from the Wardens cycle. Additionally, ten different “draft format only” cards ensure that your draft experience will be both truly dynamic and unique.

At the heart of the Westeros play experience are its randomized Westeros Draft Packs. Compiled according to a custom algorithm, and drawn from a pool of 240 pre-selected A Game of Thrones: The Card Game cards, each Draft Pack introduces a unique combination of 50 draft cards. Draft Packs are printed and made available to you via Fantasy Flight Games in-house manufacturing.

Each player in a Westeros draft will need two separate packs:

     One fixed, reusable Westeros Draft Starter pack – rules and 19 essential cards that provide the economic backbone of your deck
     One Westeros Draft pack – a selection of 50 randomized cards to be drafted


—description from the publisher
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: A Game of Thrones – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Ice and Fire Draft Pack
Description:
Ice & Fire draft products for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game introduce a new draft format for the game. Players jointly build their decks in real time from a shared pool of random cards, then test their mettle against each other using these newly-built decks.

At the heart of this alternative format are randomized Ice & Fire Draft Packs. Compiled according to a custom algorithm, and drawn from a pool of 240 pre-selected A Game of Thrones: The Card Game cards, each Draft Pack introduces a unique combination of 50 draft cards. Draft Packs are printed and made available to you via Fantasy Flight Games in-house manufacturing.

Each player in an Ice & Fire draft will need two separate packs:
1) One fixed, reusable Ice & Fire Draft Starter pack – rules and 19 essential cards that provide a foundation for your deck
2) One Ice & Fire Draft pack – a selection of 50 randomized cards to be drafted

—description from the publisher
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: A Game of Thrones – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: Which One?
Description:
Trivia game where each round presents players with a card containing 5 questions and 5 answers. Players must individually work out which answers relate to which questions.

Players can choose to gamble and guess any pairings they're unsure of, but any wrong answers will result in them getting no points from the entire card.

First player to 21 points wins.

—user summary

Name: Naval Command: Modern Naval Wargame Rules
Description:
Naval Command is a set of wargame rules for recreating naval battles with fleets of miniature warships and aircraft in the age of the guided missile and jet aeroplane. Covering the period from the late 1950s to the modern day or near future.

The game can be played with fleets ranging in size form one or two ships per side to full sized battlegroups of ten or more ships. The rules can be used for different sizes of ships ranging from small fast attack craft up to super-carriers engaged in open sea battles or littoral and amphibious missions.

The aim of these rules is to create a game that captures the feel and provides a fairly accurate recreation of modern naval engagements but is still relatively quick to play with reasonably sized fleets and does not require excessive bookkeeping and paperwork.

New 2021 Edition
This new version of the rules is the culmination of years of playing the game and the execellent feedback and expertise provided by the Naval Command Facebook group. As well as lots of small improvements and updates the follwing changes have been made:

New system for submarine deployment, movement, and detection that will require players to carry out effective ASW tactics.
The addition of altitude levels for aircraft and missiles meaning that different air defence systems now have more well defined roles.
Improved missile and torpedo procedures
Updated and expanded fleet lists.
—description from the designer on wargamevault.com

Name: Combat Team Command: Wargame Rules for Cold War and Modern Combined Arms Combat
Description:
Combat Team Command is a set of miniature wargame rules that allow players to take on the role of a battlegroup commander in charge of a combined arms force using small scale miniatures such as 1/300, 1/285, 10mm or 15mm.

The rules provided in this book deal primarily with the cold war period, notably a hypothetical third world war during the 1980s. The rules can be used to fight earlier or later conflicts. Army lists for the following conflicts are included


     1980s Cold War Gone Hot
     Arab Israeli Wars
     1991 Gulf War


The key focus of these rules is on the effective command and control or a player’s force. It is vital for players to correctly assign orders to the formations and units under the command of their officers to keep them fighting effectively.

The rules also use a card driven activation system that successfully creates a "fog of war" and keeps both players busy all the time.

—description from the publisher

Name: Cavalier: Miniature Wargame Rules for the Age of Pike & Shot
Description:
Cavalier is a set of miniature wargame rules for fighting large skirmishes from the age of pike and shot covering the period from the mid 16th century to the late 17th century.

The rules can be used to play battles from any of the many conflicts of this war-torn period such as the Italian Wars, the Thirty Years War and the English Civil Wars.

The game has been designed with 28mm miniatures in mind however there is the flexibility to use any scale with any system of basing. Games will usually involve small forces of 30 to 100 men or horse and can be played in a few hours.

Standardised stats are included for unit types of the period giving players the flexibility to build any unit they wish be it fictional or historical.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fireteam Modern (Second Edition): Wargame Rules for Modern Combat Operations
Description:
Fireteam Modern is a set of small unit skirmish wargame rules for modern combined arms land combat using 15-28mm scale miniatures. The rules can be used to fight battles from any post WW2 conflict dating from the 1950s to the modern day or the near future.

These rules have been designed to work with opposing forces of approximately platoon size with additional reinforcements such as small numbers of armoured vehicles and light artillery support.

This is a new and updated version of the rules including improved game mechanics and a new points system to allow players to create stats for any force or vehicle they want to use.

—description from the publisher

Name: Battleship Command: WWII Naval Wargame Rules
Description:
The game of Battleship Command allows players to take on the role of Second World war admirals commanding squadrons and fleets in the many theatres of the war at sea.

The rules are designed for players to command fleets of one to 10 ships however larger actions can be fought if players wish. The rules are intended to be fast to play allowing an action to be fought to a conclusion within a few hours of play.

Battleship Command also includes a new command and control system where the quality of the officers under your command can have a major impact on the game.

The rulebook includes all the rules needed to play, generic and historical scenarios as well as ship and aircraft data for the British Royal Navy, the Kriegsmarine, French Navy, Regia Marina, US Navy and the Imperial Japanese Navy.

—description from the publisher

Name: Rise of the Battleships: Pre-dreadnought Naval Wargame Rules
Description:
Rise of the Battleships is a set of naval wargame rules covering the later ironclad and pre-dreadnought era of naval warfare including the period from the 1870s to 1905.

The rules are primarily designed for small fleet actions with up to 10 ships per side however rules are included to play battles with much larger fleets.

—description from the publisher

Name: Target Locked-On: Modern Air Combat Wargame Rules
Description:
Target Locked On! is a set of miniature wargame rules designed to play air combat engagements from the cold war, modern day or near future with jet aircraft. The rules are designed to be simple, fast and most importantly fun to play.

—description from the publisher

Name: Desktop Curling
Description:
Challenge your friends and family to a game of patience and skill with this portable, miniature version of curling. This kit includes:
    12" extendable curling lane, with two platform inserts.
    8 curling stones (4 red and 4 blue)
    2 mini brooms
    32-page illustrated mini book with the rules and history to this unique winter sport

Name: Hide-and-Seek with the Bruin Boys
Description:
Contained in the Jack and Jill Book of Games and Puzzles 1969 (pp. 20-21), which has a 1968 copyright. A luck-based roll and move game, but with a couple differences from most such games:

1) Most of the spaces, which make up an horizontal figure 8, have an arrow on them (all pointing forwards); the intersection space has two arrows. Players may choose to start on any of these spaces.

2) The goal of the game is not to reach the end of the track (as there is no end), but rather to be the first one to land on all of the 8 spaces which have pictures of one of the Bruin Boys on them.

Name: Caption This!
Description: A party game of the internet's most epic fails!  Similar to Cards Against Humanity, but the judge draws a picture (Fail Card) for which the other players then submit their best caption cards.  The player who submitted the best caption during a turn wins the Fail Card, and the player who collects a certain threshold of Fail Cards wins the game.

Name: 5150: Fighter Command – Carrier Command
Description:
5150: Carrier Command can be played in a variety of ways:

You can play as the Commander of a Star Carrier with flights of Fighters/Bombers.

You can play as the Commander of one Capital Ship chosen from over a dozen types and a variety of Races.

You can play one-off battles.

You can play the full campaign with up to fifteen scenarios.

Inside you’ll find:
Detailed yet simple rules for CapShip combat with stats and counters for a variety of Races and types.

Fifteen scenarios linked together in order to tell your story as the Commander of the Star Carrier Daedalus.

A minimal bookkeeping Campaign System that gives meaning to every game as the results of one will affect the outcome of the next.

A copy of 5150: Fighter Command is required.

Name: 5150: New Hope City PI
Description:
A stand alone game that may be played can be played with 5150 Back Alleys, Bright Lights; 5150 No Limits; 5150 Fringe Space; and Chain Reaction!.

What: Private Investigating in the 5150 Universe.
Scale: 1 figure equals 1 man.
Your Role: You're a Private Investigator or Police Detective; your choice.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.

When the Cops Just Won't Do.

In New Hope City PI you’re a Private Investigator. When the cops won’t do, they hire you. If you want to be a Police Detective instead, you can still use these rules. In fact you can use these rules for investigating in any gaming period, with any Two Hour Wargames rules.

As a PI you’ll be offered a variety of Crimes to solve from Robbery to Murder. The way to solve a Crime is to find a certain number of Clues based on how difficult the Case is. The more difficult the Case the more Clues you need to find. This can be either finding an Object or Questioning a Person of Interest.

Sounds simple enough but you’ll be facing twists and turns as you’ll be moving through all the levels of society in New Hope City, from the Movers and Shakers to the Criminal Element as well.

Inside you’ll find:

The 5150 Basic Sci Fi Combat rules making this a standalone game.
Details on five types of Crimes and how they differ.
A system to generate and solve Clues, based on your Character's abilities.
Eleven different neighborhoods to adventure in plus a Transit System to move from area to area seamlessly.
Thirteen Alien Races including eight new ones.
Mechanics to generate hundreds of Cases with no two ever being exactly alike.
Over 50 Professions to generate Victims, Suspects and People of Interest.
Info on the Operators from the Department of Home Security and their mysterious prey, the Cyndees.
Introducing the Gene Altering Xenoform or GAX for short. Seeing isn't always believing.
All this and much more...

-description from publisher's website

Name: 5150: Star Army  – 2nd Tour
Description:
What: Sci-Fi Squad/Platoon size combat.
Scale: Man to man combat. 1 figure equals 1 man.
Your Role: Players can command from one Squad to a full Company of infantry.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.
5150 Star Army can be played in a variety of ways:
You can play as a Squad Leader with a full Squad.
You can play as a Squad Leader with less than a full Squad.
You can play as a Platoon Leader with a full Platoon of multiple Squads.
You can play as a Company Commander with multiple Platoons.

The bottom line is you can play it any way you like, with any figures you may already have or with the included color counters.

Inside you’ll find:
A man to man skirmish combat system that plays fast and yields realistic results.
Over a dozen different Factions to choose from, including the Bugs.
Stats for over sixteen different weapons.
A Promotion system that allows your troops to rise in rank and ability
The Reaction System that allows you to play the game solo, co-cooperatively or head to head.
A minimal bookkeeping Campaign System that gives meaning to every game as the results of one will affect the outcome of the next.

-description from publisher's website

Name: ゾンビランドサガ 君の心にナイスゲームSAGA (ZombieLand Saga: Kimi no kokoro ni naisugēmu SAGA)
Description:
ã‚¾ãƒ³ãƒ“ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ‰ã‚µã‚¬ å›ã®å¿ƒã«ãƒŠã‚¤ã‚¹ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ SAGA (ZombieLand Saga - Kimi no kokoro ni naisugÄ“mu SAGA) (ZombieLand Saga - A nice SAGA game in your heart) is based on the hit anime "Zombieland Saga". You and up to four other players take the role of mysterious Idol Producer Kotaro Tatsumi as he tries to lead the idol group Franchouchou to fame and save Saga - all while making sure no one knows the idol group are zombies.

In this resource management game each player needs to balance their time between training the group, working part-time jobs, and selecting the best girls to perform Lives (concerts).

While the main way to earn fans in this game (Victory Points) is to perform the Lives you must be careful, because after each concert the participating girl's make-up is used up and they turn back into their Zombie form.

Name: Shipwreck: Scenario 02 – Operation Praying Mantis
Description:
Operation Praying Mantis is a ready to play scenario based on Operation Praying Mantis, the first ever guided missile engagement fought by the US Navy.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile, with a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action, results and long-term consequences.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, instructions to set up the scenario, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Scenario 03 – the Bubiyan Turkey-Shoot
Description:
The Bubiyan Turkey-Shoot is a ready to play scenario based on operations against an Iraqi amphibious assault in the 1990-91 Gulf War.

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions, variants and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 01: The Assault on South Georgia
Description:
Corporate Rosario 01 - the assault on South Georgia is the first in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.  Variants include fighting the engagement as if the war was fought in 1972, 1992, 2002 or 2012!


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 02: the Empire strikes back
Description:
Corporate Rosario 02 - the Empire strikes back

is the second in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

The British task force closes in and begins to bombard the Argentine defences.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 03: The Three Musketeers
Description:
Corporate Rosario 03 - the Three Musketeers is the third in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A small British squadron runs the gauntlet of mines, fast attack craft, submarines and aircraft to dash in and conduct a surface bombardment.

Designed for SOLO play, but can be used for two or more players.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 04: Breaking the Pincer
Description:
Corporate Rosario 04 - breaking the pincer is the fourth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A British submarine hunts a small Argentine squadron.  A scenario based on the sinking of the old Argentine cruiser General Belgrano.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 05: Enter the Ring
Description:
Corporate Rosario 05 - Enter the ring is the Fifth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

This is the big one!  The closest that the two sides came to a major fleet action, in real life frustrated by poor weather.  This illustrates what could have happened, as Argentine task forces move on the British task force.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 06: Rolling Back the Pickets
Description:
Corporate Rosario 06 - Rolling back the pickets Sixth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the May 4th 1982 attack that sank the British Destroyer HMS Sheffield, the first use of the devestating exocet anti-ship missile.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.



     Optional variations to refight the action in 1972 and 1992


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 07: Encounters in the Sound
Description:
Corporate Rosario 07 - Encounters in the Sound is the seventh in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the transit of the British frigate HMS Alacrity through the narrow Fallkland Sound, braving mines, shore batteries, fast attack craft and submarines, and all with a time limit!  For two players, but suitable for solo play too.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


Optional variations to refight the action in 1972, 1992 and 2002!

—description from the publisher

Name: Azrah: War of Heralds
Description:
Welcome to Azrah, a mystical realm of cosmic energies.
You are a Herald - one of many celestial beings tasked with protecting the realm from sinister influences and perpetual discord.  As a Herald, you have often dispatched your chosen champions, known as "Guardians," to preserve the balance. Now, an umbral otherworldly force, "The Nether," has come to Azrah and has corrupted some Heralds and their Guardians. All-out war has broken out! It's time to call upon your Guardians once again and defeat the corrupted!

Azrah: War of Heralds is a complete tactical card game for two players. Both players build their own fantasy party using a roster of "Guardian" characters, then use their party to defeat their opponent. Each Guardian draws from a familiar fantasy archetype, such as the Paladin, Warlock, and Assassin.

Azrah features elements of deckbuilding, drafting, and resource management, as well as a party-based combat system. Both players begin a game with five health. The objective is to reduce your opponent to zero health by defeating Guardians in their party.

—description from the designer

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 08: Operation Sutton
Description:
Corporate Rosario 08 - Operation Sutton is the eighth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the opening day of "Operation Sutton", the British landing on the Falkland Islands.  Can they repulse wave after wave of Jet fighter-bombers?

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 09: Bomb Alley
Description:
Corporate Rosario 09 - Bomb Alley is the ninth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the thrid day of "Operation Sutton", the British landing on the Falkland Islands.  The initial flurry of knee-jerk air attacks is over.  Both sides have had a chance to evaluate and alter their tactics.  Who has done the better job?

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: 電力会社対助役 (Power Co. vs Mayor)
Description:
The game é›»åŠ›ä¼šç¤¾å¯¾åŠ©å½¹ (Power Co. vs Mayor) is a postcard game pitting one player representing the power company against the other player who takes on the roll of the mayor.

Players must supply their own components: 1 six-sided dice, 4 cubes, and components to use as money.  The game takes place over 4 rounds, each consisting of three phases.

In each of the rounds, the mayor and the power company representative will each have a chance to roll the die, hiding the value, and state a number. Depending upon the other player's choice, one player collects money and the other adjusts the cubes that represent the income of the power plants.  Afterwards, the power company collects income.

The postcard shows 4 power plants.  In the first round, the player only collects income from the first plant.  In the second round, the player collects income from the first and second plant, etc.

The player with the most money after 4 rounds wins.

Name: Shipwreck: Submarines!
Description:
Submarines! is a set of ship detail sheets for Submarines, for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.


     128 pages, 
     120 visual representation of different submarine classes from 25 nations.  


A great boon to your Shipwreck gaming!

—description from the publisher

Name: Amazing Jungle Run
Description:
You never thought your dream vacation would be like this!
You were expecting lavish huts and guided tours. Instead you were dropped off to fend for yourself in a jungle full of wild animals. You've always stood up to face challenges, and it's no time to stop now. Can you summon your skills to master the animals, find the most food, and emerge "King of the Jungle"?
Get ready, let's explore....

In Amazing Jungle Run, you'll compete to be the first player to reach 9 points. Points are collected by earning "fruit" cards or the valuable Shaman card, which is worth 3 points all by itself.

A players turn consists of three phases:

     Action phase in which you can choose Resource cards, Peril cards, or peek at the bottom of main decks to see what may be hiding there.
     Main phase in which you can choose to collect common cards(to gain 3 of a kind for special abilities) or "point" cards that get you closer to the win. Some resource cards allow you to do both in one turn. A player can manipulate decks with cards like "hideaway", "transport", or "explore" during this phase.
     Defense phase in which you can keep a deck "off limits" or limit your opponents options with "quicksand".


The game invites imaginative play to form strategies, and tactical opportunities abound. The "hidden" knowledge aspect of being able to play from the bottom of decks keeps you on your toes.

Tension builds as the decks dwindle, and the higher points cards (planted in the bottom half of decks during setup)start to appear.

Have fun and be wary of pitfalls....it's a jungle out there.

—description from the publisher

Name: Doggy Bag
Description:
Flip a card to find out what food Franky the dog choses. Then, put a hand in your bag to find the food shown on the card and give it to Franky. No cheating, you are not allowed to look in your bag! You should only use the sense of touch when blindly palpating the food in your Doggy Bag. The first player to give Franky the dog 5 food items wins the game!

—description from the publisher (translated)

Retournez une carte pour connaître l’aliment que Franky le chien a choisi. Ensuite, plongez une main dans votre sac pour découvrir l’aliment illustré sur la carte et le donner à Franky. Pas de tricherie, vous n’avez pas le droit de regarder dans votre sac! Vous devez seulement utiliser le sens du toucher en palpant à l’aveugle les aliments contenus dans votre « Doggy Bag ». Le premier joueur qui donne 5 aliments à Franky le chien remporte la partie!

—description from the publisher

Name: Kodama 3D: Decree Expansion
Description:
This 14 card set contains 5 additional goal cards, 8 decree cards, and 1 rules card.

This set was only included exclusively during the KS campaign, but may be available at conventions or via other sources later.

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 10 - The National day attack
Description:
Corporate Rosario 10 - The National day attack is the  tenth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the attack upon the 42/22 picket combination of HMS Coventry and HMS Broadsword.  Variations include the action refought in 1972, 1992, 2002 and 2012.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:

A description of the action and results.

Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.

—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 11: Bluff Cove disaster
Description:
Corporate Rosario 11 - Bluff Cove disaster is the eleventh in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the attack on British landing ships at Bluff Cove, the greatest single loss of life for the British in the Falklands war.  Variations include the action refought in 1972, 1992 and 2002.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 12: Exocet vs Carriers
Description:
Corporate Rosario 12 - Exocet vs Carriers is the twelfth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the last air-launched exocet attack on the British carriers.  One last attempt by Argentina for victory at sea.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher

Name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 13: The Last Missiles
Description:
Corporate Rosario 13 - The last missiles is the thirteenth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the last serious air attack on the British carriers.  Using tankers the Argentines got their aircraft into a flank position.  Can surprise make up for lack of numbers and technology?

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.  With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


     A description of the action and results.



     Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.  Variations for refighting the action in 1972 and 2012!


—description from the publisher

Name: The Catholic Card Game: Generations Expansion Pack
Description: This expansion for the Catholic Card Game includes 12 yellow prompt cards and 42 white answer cards in their own tuck box. Half of the cards revolve around Baby Boomers (printed in LARGER FONT) and the other half are all about Millennials.

Name: The Catholic Card Game: Life Teen Expansion Pack
Description: This expansion for the Catholic Card Game, which includes 9 yellow prompt cards and 45 white answer cards in their own tuck box, was made in collaboration with the people at Life Teen.

Name: The Catholic Card Game: Five Deck Expansion Pack
Description: This set of expansions for the Catholic Card Game includes 215 cards (21 yellow prompt cards and 194 white answer cards) designed in conjunction with Catching Foxes, Pints with Aquinas, Tomics Comics, The Crunch, and Fr. Mike Schmitz.

Name: Saucy Grannies
Description:
Saucy Grannies is a competitive, light and family-friendly card game featuring blind bidding, card drafting and set collection mechanics.

You play as a granny participating in a neighbourhood cook-off where the sauce is everything. Score points by sending your family members to the market to purchase choice ingredients, call up your granny friends for their signature sauce recipes and impress the judges by making the best sauces at your disposal!

The player with the most points after 9 rounds is declared the sauciest granny!

You'll love Saucy Grannies if you: 


     Enjoy collection and building games.
     Delight in outwitting your friends with sneaky tactics.
     Thrive on uncertainty by capitalising on probability.
     Are looking for a light, introductory game that can be taught in 5 and played in 30 minutes.


—description from the publisher

Name: Evolution: Venom
Description:
Promo cards created for The Secret Cabal 2018 Kickstarter campaign.  Contains 7 Venom trait cards for the base game, Evolution.

Venom
Disregard Body Size when attacking.
This species may only make 1 attack during each Feeding Phase.

Name: What Do You Meme?: NSFW Expansion Deck
Description:
Warning: Mature Content! This new expansion for What Do You Meme? party game includes 90 new ADULT caption cards.

—description from the publisher

Name: Warfighter: Modern PMC Expansion #44 – Money!
Description:
Adds 56 cards to your PMC core game! Includes a little bit of everything from PMC Soldiers to Action cards!

—description from the publisher

Name: All Things Zombie: High Rise to Hell
Description:
A supplement for All Things Zombie - Final Fade Out and contains the following:

A complete, occupied nine story high rise to explore and adventure in

Smart Vampires

Vampires

Werewolves

Magic Casters

Name: Black Seas: Smugglers Run
Description:
Smuggler’s Run puts two players at the heart of this black market, running contraband in and out of the British Isles. Create your own smuggling company and outwit the authorities in the name of trade and profit!

Smuggler’s Run is a two-player campaign where two rival smuggling companies compete to ferry the most contraband into the United Kingdom. Both players should have already created a smuggling company. On the (miniature) high seas, players will alternate commanding their villainous flotilla and the various customs boats patrolling the coastline.

—description from the publisher

Name: 95th: Man-to-Man Skirmish Combat in the Napoleonic Wars
Description:
What: Wargame/RPG rules for small fights in the Peninsula War from 1808 - 1814.
Scale: Man to man combat. 1 figure equals 1 man.
Your Role: Players can command from one small group to multiple groups as you rise in Rank.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.

95th can be played in a variety of ways:
You can play as a member of a small band of soldiers.
You can play as the Leader of a small band of soldiers.
You can play larger games with multiple bands of soldiers.
The bottom line is you can play it any way you like, with any figures or counters you like.

Inside you’ll find:
60 full color card stock counters to get you into the game ASAP.
Rules for skirmish combat built around the famous British 95th Rifles
Four Armies to choose from - British, French, Portuguese and Spanish as well as Lists for Deserters, Guerrillas and the Civilian population
Nineteen different infantry and cavalry units to play as.
Fourteen different Missions for you to play.
A system that rewards your men when successful and punishes them when they fail; rising in Rank as you play.
Different Attributes that help make your Characters unique.
A minimal bookkeeping Campaign System that gives meaning to every game as the results of one will affect the outcome of the next.

Name: Muskets & Shakos: The Napoleonic Wars 1803-1815
Description:
Muskets and Shakos is a unit based game where units are composed of 2 to 20 figures. In Muskets and Shakos you can choose from two sides, with a total of seven factions. In Muskets and Shakos you can command a division of troops, chosen from the following list:

French (including French satellites).
Austrian.
British (often including allied troops such as the Portuguese.
Prussian.
Russian.
Spanish.
Turks (both the forces of the Sultan and the Mamelukes).

Whichever you choose you must lead your men through the war, the Napoleonic War, fighting when needed because it’s all about victory and glory, and in some cases, just survival!

Muskets and Shakos shares game mechanics with our popular French & Indian War rules set, Muskets and Mohawks. If you already have Mohawks you have a leg up on learning Shakos, but if you don’t, no need to worry. We’ve broken the rules down into smaller pieces with examples and small exercises to make learning the game a snap.

Name: Morale Napoleon: Grand Tactical Rules for the Napoleonic Wars
Description:
It wasn’t Napoleon or Wellington’s duty to order units to fire, charge or change formation. That is the duty of others, of the battalion and regimental officers. Where Morale Napoleon excels is in allowing players to “do their duty”. You are in charge of a Corps of soldiers ranging in size from 20,000 to 40,000 men. Once you become comfortable with the rules, you can easily double those numbers. Your duty is simple:

Have a plan. Deploy your troops to accomplish your plan. Decide where to place your reserve and when to use it. In Morale Napoleon, once you have sent your troops into action, it is out of your control, just like in real life. Did you plan well? Is your deployment correct? Will you know when the moment is right to launch the reserve? Do you have what it takes to be in command?

Regimental size formations that allow you to easily command a Corps or more. Mechanics that provide a fun game with realistic conclusions – no “gaming the rules”.

Army lists for over 20 of the nations that fought in the Napoleonic Wars – from the major players to their smaller allies.

Reinforcement tables that reflect Napoleon’s dictum of march divided, fight united.

Complete rules that allow you to pay solo or co-operatively against the game as well as competitively, head to head.

A light book keeping Campaign System that ties your battles together while giving you a reason to fight and telling you when all is lost.

Name: Roland Wright: The Dice Game –  Board Game Trends
Description:
The "Board Game Trends" card set is a mini-expansion included with the Kickstarter edition of Roland Wright: The Dice Game. It adds some new board game trend cards that add in more ways to score points.

COMPLETING A BOARD GAME TREND CARD: This card is an additional, public card that players may complete during the game. Immediately after you complete the pattern, write in the point value in the green "Hallmark" score space on your Player Board. The first player(s) to do so will earn 8 points. All players that complete the pattern on the same turn receive the same point value. A player completing the pattern on a later turn checks the lowest value that any other player earned on a previous turn, then writes in the next lowest value on their board.

Name: High Moon: Dead Reckoning
Description:
High Moon is a stand-alone game that brings the world of Horror to the Old West, but if you want, you can play it as a straight up Western game. In High Moon – Dead Reckoning you’ll find rules for a variety of supernatural creatures as well as natural ones. Designed to be playable with any figures, you can play solo, as a team or even against opponents!

High Moon - Dead Reckoning can be played in a variety of ways and contains the following:

A variety of Races including Humans, Vampires, Werewolves, Witches, Zombies, and much more.
Over 30 different Professions to breathe life into your characters.
Rules for your characters to grow in skills and abilities as they succeed.
30+ Attributes to further define your characters.
A quick and easy to use Magic system for you to use.
A system that generates your adventures for you.
Totally compatible with Six Gun Sound.

Name: Old Trousers II: Warfare in the Horse & Musket Era – Battalion Level Napoleonic Warfare
Description:
Old Trousers is a set of battalion-level miniatures battle rules for the Napoleonic period.

Each base of 2-4 figures represents one infantry company, cavalry squadron, or artillery battery.

The rules are freely available online.

—user summary

Name: Schnapp die Möpse: Rainbow Wars Erweiterung
Description:
Rainbow Wars is the first expansion for the card game Schnapp die Möpse and consists of 54 Game Cards of which 39 are beautifully illustrated.

This expansion you not only get well known action cards but a lot of new aggressor and defense cards along with new "No"-Cards, which help to save your hand against attackers.
You get new "addional cards" which help to play two cards oder make a normal card impenetrable against deactivation.

Really helpful is a new reaction card which allows you to tell a player to play a no-card for you.

In Rainbow Wars we get a common enemy in form of a rainbow cat which is able to steal the unicorm pugs. Distract it with laser pointers or defeat it with the unicorn pug.

Play with up to 7 players.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Rainbow Wars ist die erste Erweiterung für das Kartenspiel Schnapp die Möpse und besteht aus 54 Spielkarten, wovon 39 Spielkarten mit schönen neuen Illustrationen ausgeschmückt wurden.

Die Erweiterung zum Grund-Kartenspiel bietet neben einigen wenigen bekannten, eine Menge toller neuer Aktionskarten, mit denen man noch mehr Angriffs-, sowie Verteidigungsmöglichkeiten erhält.
Neben einer neuen "Nein-Karte", gibt es auch diverse Zusatzkarten mit denen man unter anderem gleich 2 Aktionskarten spielen darf, einen Mops mit einem weiteren Mopspunkt ausstatten oder sogar eine Aktionskarte durchboxen kann, damit sie gar nicht erst mit einer Nein-Karte aufgehoben werden darf.

Sehr hilfreich ist eine neue Reaktionskarte mit der man einen beliebigen Möpsemopser dazu zwingen kann eine Nein-Karte zu spielen. Natürlich geht dies nur, wenn er eine zum Ausspielen besitzt.

In Rainbow Wars kommt ein gemeinsamer Gegner ins Spiel: Die Regenbogen Katze. Lenke sie mit Laserpointern ab oder besiege sie mit dem Einhornmops.

Nun kann auch mit bis zu 7 Spielern gespielt werden.

—description from the publisher

Name: Connecticut
Description:
Connecticut is a drawless connection game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. The suggested board size is 19x19. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white.

				
				
					PlayBlack plays first, by putting a single stone down on the board, then turns alternate.

On subsequent turns, either player may either place a single stone down on the board or a 1x3 triomino.

The game is won by the player who completes a chain of orthogonally or diagonally adjacent stones of their color touching the two opposite board edges of their color. Draws are not possible.

				
				
					Pie ruleThe pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means that White will have the option, on his first turn only, to change sides instead of making a regular move.

Name: Lost Halls of the Mountain King
Description:
Each player is the leader of a clan of Dwarves returning to a lost mountain kingdom. Players are competing with each other to remove threats, find artifacts, complete tasks, and earn honor. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game becomes the new King of the reclaimed mountain.

It is fundamentally a worker placement game, but with many rules that increase player interaction. Players compete to recruit four different worker types as they also compete to utilize locations before their opponents.

The board is made up of 20 halls, semi-randomly placed at the start of the game. The top 8 halls were undefended, but the lower 12 halls have threats that must be cleared before they can be accessed.

Each hall has one or two labors that can be performed in them. Each labor requires a particular type of dwarf, and often will require a team of dwarves plus other resources to be completed. Each labor offers its own rewards, from honor or gold, or mine cards, or artifacts, or retaining more dwarves to a players palace.

A particular labor can only be used from one to four times a year, so players are competing to use use labors before each other. Because labors have different requirements to complete, they are also competing to gather the types of dwarves needed for the labors they want to perform.

There are four kinds of dwarves: Workers, Warriors, Craftsmen, and Nobles. They are generally used for the kinds of labors one might expect from their names.

Unlike most worker placement games, the players do not have their own pieces. There are common pools of dwarves available, and the players take or assign dwarves from those common pools. One pool is a hall called The Commons, which has dwarves ready to work in them. Players can use one dwarf from The Commons on each of their turns. Dwarves are also in The Camp outside of the mountain, recovering or resting until  players recruit them to their palaces.

Play goes around the table, with players selecting a labor they want to perform in a hall, or a threat they want to remove. When a threat is removed, the hall it guarded is revealed and the player effectively gets a free turn to be the first to perform a labor in the hall.

Players can obtain mine cards that will have either gold, iron, gems or mithril. Gold is turned in immediately, while the other three are kept secret until they are used to complete a labor or a task.

There are also Tasks which the players can complete to earn victory points, which generally require four or five resources.

Artifacts may be gained in several ways, and provide victory points as well as the opportunity to attract a dwarf from the Camp when it is revealed. They are a way to hide your possible activities from your opponents.

The game is played in five segments, each representing a year, though players can agree to shorter games by reducing the number of years played. A year ends when The Commons is empty of Dwarves and a player passes. That player will be the first player for the following year. Then the dwarves out in the halls return to The Commons to be available for the next year.

Many of the threats have year-end effects that can remove dwarves from The Commons, remove them from the players' palaces, take gold or mine cards, re-close halls, or even remove a hall from the game.

Players are also determining what kind of values the reclaimed kingdom will be known for. There are four Dwarven virtues - Military, Craft, Wealth, and Heritage. Players can promote these virtues by completing Tasks and performing Labors. The most promoted virtues can earn players bonus points at the end of the game for each Task they completed or Artifact they acquired associated with those virtues.

The combination of randomly placed hidden halls and randomly placed threats with varying effects provides an enormous amount of replayability. Players need to consider the kinds of labors and threats that are present when devising their plans, as well as what dwarves are available in The Commons.

It is a victory point gathering game. There are six ways to earn VP:
Rewards for a Labor
Completing a Task
Acquiring Artifacts
Clearing Threats
Bonus points for clearing the most threats 
Bonus Points for matching Tasks and Artifacts to the most promoted Dwarven Virtues

-description from designer

Name: Monopoly: Voice Banking
Description:
Buy, sell, dream, and scheme with Mr. Monopoly as your Banker! Travel around the board buying properties and collecting rent. The game ends when one player goes bankrupt. Then the player with the most money and highest property value wins!

Use the voice-controlled Banker to keep track of your money, pay rent, collect Go, buy properties, and much more!

Name: Monopoly: Disney Frozen II
Description:
Similarly to the base game players journey round the board, buying properties (which in this case are scenes from the first and second films), charging rent and making deals.

The stations of the original game have been replaced by elements which allow players to teleport around the board.  The utilities are “snowflake” spaces, which give the opportunity to tell a heart warming memory to gain the snowflake token, which then doubles the rent on one property.

—user summary

Name: Missile Threat: Solo Rules & Mercenary Air Campaign
Description:
Missile Threat Solo Rules & Mercenary Air Campaign: this book gives you everything you need to play Missile Threat solo and to play the Mercenary Air Campaign.

The Solo Rules:

These include all the rules needed for solo games, as well as random aircraft tables for every conflict and faction covered in Missile Threat. Random Ground Asset and Naval Vessel tables are also included. The solo game relies on regular playing cards to generate unknown hostile aircraft and ground assets, so prepare to be surprised!

The Mercenary Air Campaign:

Manage a group of fictitious Mercenaries as you purchase aircraft and ordnance, select missions, get paid and attempt to survive! This campaign runs on the basic Missile Threat rules, and is aimed at solo play but can easily be a co-operative game. Players start with a selection of pilots and a pool of funds and must purchase aircraft and ordnance from a weapons market. They then use what they have to fly available missions and if they succeed: get paid.

The Mercenary air campaign is all about the "rule of cool" - you won't be limited to light attack aircraft, but rather any aircraft around in your chosen theater, period and faction. The campaign uses the Complete Aircraft & Ordnance List provided with the Missile Threat rules, and allows you to buy and fly many of the more unusual or lesser used aircraft from the last 60 years, as well as the regulars.

The Mercenary air campaign has 3 difficulty options, ranging from easy mode with 4 pilots and a sh*tload of cash, to the hard mode of a lone wolf pilot with the last of his savings.

There are 5 different periods to choose from: 1960s, 1970s, 1980s, 1990s and 2000s+

Each period has 5 different theaters to play in: Balkans/Eastern Europe, Central/South Africa, Middle East, South America, and South-East Asia

Each theater has 2 factions you can work for: Either the government or the rebels.

In this way there are 50 different options for playing the campaign. You could be working for the rebels in South America in the 1990s, or working for the government in the Middle East in the 1960s. Each option has a customized random aircraft and ordnance table to reflect the period, theater and alignment. That's 100 D66 tables!

—description from the publisher

Name: Glory and Honour: Army Level Wargame Rules & Campaign System for The Seven Years War in Central Europe (1756-1763)
Description:
Glory & Honour - Army Level Wargame Rules & Campaign System for The Seven Years War in Central Europe (1756-1763)

The campaign game covers the Seven Years War in Central Europe (mainly Bohemia, Saxony & Silesia) during which Prussia fought a bitter and protracted war with Austria and her allies. The battlefield rules emphasise troop quality, ability of generals, role of light troops and the decisive effect of massed cavalry. Depending on the battlefield results and the occupation of key cities the Diplomatic Chart will influence the political stance of France, Sweden, Russia and the minor German States. These may add forces to one side or call for withdrawal of friendly forces to observe and deter these states.

Contents:  51 page Gamebook, A4 set of campaign counters, Allied Armies Strength Table, Prussian Armies strength Table, Honour Points Cards, Political Chart, Campaign Calendar, Playing the Cards Chart, Battlefield Creator Chart and a two-page Playsheet (one for the Campaign System one for the Battlefield). There is also 2A3 Campaign map or 4 A4 Campaign maps (depending upon your printer).

Scale


     Ground Scale: 1” = 100 metres. Movement is 5” for artillery, 10” for Infantry & 20” for Cavalry



     Time Scale: 1 Turn = 15-20 minutes



     Table Size: 5-6 x 4 ft.



     Figure/Base ratio: Figures per base according to pocket. We use Pendraken’s 10 mm figures with 6 infantry, 3 cavalry, 3 light troops or 1 gun and 2-3 crew per base. With 4 - 8 Bases per Infantry or Cavalry Brigade. Ratio is approx. 1:50 to 1:80.



     Game Length: 2 – 4 hours depending on size of battle


—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: "An' go to your Gawd like a soldier": Small Wars on the North-West Frontier
Description:
An' Go to Gawd like a soldier - Ruleset for Gaming Small Wars in the North West Frontier

A game for up to 4 Players who will play as Tribal leaders trying to improve their status and power in the wild North-West Frontier. They will also play as Imperialists to command a column against the other players attempting to crush and humiliate the other tribes.

The player with the least number of districts will play as Imperialist Column Commander if a tabletop action is fought. If two or more have the least number of districts then it will be a jointly commanded operation. The others make the tea and heckle as each game should only take a couple of hours.

—description from the publisher

Name: "This War Without An Enemy": English Civil War Battlefield Rules & County-Based Campaign System
Description:
This War Without an Enemy - English Civil War Battlefield Rules  & County-Based Campaign System

The English Civil War when gamed at County level gives great opportunities for gaming this fascinating period. You have the problem of controlling areas for your cause, denying them to your enemy and yet always at the whim of the King or Parliament in providing the great central field armies with resources. The great National events of the great battles or the support of the Scots or the arrival of the great central field armies as they maraud through your county makes for a most unpredictable game.

The novel battlefield rules emphasise the limitations of command and allow the games to flow fast and furious such that they are often over in a couple of hours or the time they would have been fought in reality.

Scope: Included are a set of battlefield figure rules for fighting battles up to 6,000- 8,000 men with a full colour Campaign system to fight the war. Thus your battles will have a context of when and why they were fought. There is also a system for fighting one-off battles.

Contents: 56  page Gamebook, 2 x A4 Unit Counters, 1 x A4 Game Counters, A4 sheet of Fate cards Campaign Calendar, 2 x A4 Off-Table Charts, There is a two-page Playsheet (one for the Campaign System one for the Battlefield) and 2 A3 or 4 A4 map of  Worcestershire.

Scales


     Ground Scale: 1” = 10 yards/metres. All combat and movement are by handspan or 6” rules. So a battle is approx. half a mile by a third of a mile



     Time Scale: 1 Turn = 10-15 minutes



     Table Size: 6 x 4 ft. up to 8 x 6 ft.
